bioghist.p: Douglas V. Steere (1901-1995) taught philosophy at Haverford College from 1928 to 1964, serving as chair of the department for a number of years. He later served as a senior advisor for the Margaret Gest Center for Cross-Cultural Study of Religion. After his retirement in 1964, he represented the Society of Friends as one of the 17 Protestant churchmen from the United States observing Vatican Council II. He also helped organize the Ecumenical Institute of Spirituality. He served as Chairman of the Friends World Committee for Consultation from 1964 to 1970. He and his wife Dorothy helped to found Pendle Hill, a Quaker study center in Wallingford, Pennsylvania, in 1930, and served on the Board of Managers. He was the author of numerous books, pamphlets, and articles on religious and spiritual topics.
